reporter.title: Stored XSS in transaction memo renders in banker console queue
reporter.summary: During routine exploratory testing of the transfer creation flow, I identified that user-supplied content submitted as the SEPA transfer memo is stored without server-side sanitization and later rendered into the banker console queue and detail templates using an unsafe rendering primitive. As a result, an attacker-controlled retail user can craft a transfer with a memo containing an HTML/JS payload that executes automatically in the context of any authenticated banker who views the queue or the transfer detail. This constitutes stored XSS in a high-privilege back-office surface. The absence of a restrictive Content Security Policy on the affected pages further increases exploit reliability and enables exfiltration techniques. This issue presents a realistic path to session takeover, CSRF-like privileged actions, and potential lateral movement into internal tooling that implicitly trusts banker sessions.
steps_to_reproduce: Login and initiate a SEPA transfer from Checking -> Savings.
Set memo to <svg onload=alert(1)> and submit.
Fetch created transfer via GET /api/v2/transfers/{id} and confirm raw memo is persisted.
Logout. Login as banker to https://banking.glaciervaultbank.foo/console and open Queue.
Observe alert on queue load as memo is rendered without encoding.
Navigate to transfer detail; payload executes a second time in the detail view.

impact.description: Stored XSS on banker console allows session theft, CSRF-like actions via the admin UI, and lateral movement into internal tooling that trusts banker sessions.
impact.blast_radius: Any banker viewing the queue or transfer detail is affected.

mitigation: HTML-encode untrusted data before DOM insertion (server-side templates and client renders).
Set a strict CSP: script-src 'self'; object-src 'none'; base-uri 'none'; frame-ancestors 'none'.
Strip dangerous tags and attributes on input (svg, script, onerror, onload).
Add regression tests rendering transfer memo in list and detail views.

reporter.description:
During routine exploratory testing of the transfer creation flow, I identified that user-supplied content submitted as the SEPA transfer memo is stored without server-side sanitization and later rendered into the banker console queue and detail templates using an unsafe rendering primitive. As a result, an attacker-controlled retail user can craft a transfer with a memo containing an HTML/JS payload that executes automatically in the context of any authenticated banker who views the queue or the transfer detail. This constitutes stored XSS in a high-privilege back-office surface. The absence of a restrictive Content Security Policy on the affected pages further increases exploit reliability and enables exfiltration techniques. This issue presents a realistic path to session takeover, CSRF-like privileged actions, and potential lateral movement into internal tooling that implicitly trusts banker sessions.

### Technical analysis
- Vulnerability class: **Stored/Reflected XSS**
- Affected target: `https://banking.glaciervaultbank.foo/app/transfer`
- Preconditions: authenticated user: authenticated retail user; app version: Banking UI 2025.09.12-1

```javascript
// Sanitize and HTML-encode untrusted data before DOM insertion
const unsafe = req.body.subject;
// BAD
document.querySelector('#subject').innerHTML = unsafe;
// GOOD
document.querySelector('#subject').textContent = unsafe;
```

### Why this is a security issue
The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

### Exploitation details
- Login and initiate a SEPA transfer from Checking -> Savings.
- Set memo to <svg onload=alert(1)> and submit.
- Fetch created transfer via GET /api/v2/transfers/{id} and confirm raw memo is persisted.
- Logout. Login as banker to https://banking.glaciervaultbank.foo/console and open Queue.
- Observe alert on queue load as memo is rendered without encoding.
- Navigate to transfer detail; payload executes a second time in the detail view.

### Recommendations
- HTML-encode untrusted data before DOM insertion.
- Prefer `textContent`/safe templating.
- Deploy strict CSP; strip dangerous tags/attributes.

reporter.title: IDOR in documents API reveals other customers' statements
reporter.summary: While validating access controls around statement delivery, I discovered that the `GET /api/v2/documents/{docId}` endpoint authorizes access solely based on the presence of a valid session and does not verify resource ownership. By incrementing or decrementing the numeric identifier, I was able to retrieve PDF statements belonging to other customers. The issue appears systemic across adjacent identifiers, suggesting predictable sequencing and missing object-level authorization. This leads to exposure of sensitive financial information (names, masked IBANs, account summaries) and facilitates targeted collection for high-value customers if combined with business logic and timing. Short-term mitigations include strict ownership checks and signed, time-limited URLs; long-term mitigations include using opaque identifiers and rate limiting enumeration patterns.
steps_to_reproduce: Login and obtain your latest statement ID from /api/v2/statements/last.
Call GET /api/v2/documents/{yourId} -> 200 PDF.
Increment ID: GET /api/v2/documents/{yourId+1} -> 200 PDF for a different user.
Repeat with +2, +3 to confirm enumeration; observe different names in PDF metadata.

impact.description: Disclosure of financial statements for other customers. High confidentiality breach.
impact.blast_radius: All customers whose documents IDs are guessable.

mitigation: Enforce object ownership checks (accountId matches).
Use unguessable document IDs (UUIDv4) and signed URLs with short TTL.
Add rate limiting and monitoring on document fetches.
Backfill: rotate public links, purge caches.

comments.message: Submitting PoC with 3 redacted PDFs confirming cross-account access; metadata reveals differing customer names (masked).
Issue reproducible on 2025.09.12-1. Added histogram of observed docId distribution indicating sequential allocation per shard.
Staging retest after ownership filter: enumeration now blocked (403); signed URL requires unaltered signature/expiry and rejects tampering.

reporter.title: Password reset token leak via Referer on third-party analytics
reporter.summary: The password reset flow loads a third-party analytics script on the tokenized reset page. When users click embedded help/FAQ links that navigate cross-domain, the browser includes the full URL in the Referer header, which contains the sensitive reset token. This token is then visible to the analytics vendor (and potentially to any intermediaries with log access), enabling account takeover within the token’s lifetime. The risk is exacerbated by the 30-minute TTL and the lack of referrer policy restrictions on the sensitive route. I verified leakage by inspecting requests on the analytics endpoint and confirmed that navigating away from the reset page propagates the full tokenized URL in Referer.
steps_to_reproduce: Request a reset link for your account.
Open the tokenized reset URL and click the embedded 'help' link to the knowledge base (different domain).
Observe that the analytics endpoint receives a request with the Referer header leaking the full tokenized reset URL.

proof_of_concept.notes: Token TTL observed at ~30 minutes; vendor logs likely persist for days or longer.

impact.description: Token leakage enables account takeover within token TTL if intercepted by third party or logs.
impact.blast_radius: Any resetting user who clicks cross-domain links.

mitigation: Serve reset flow without third-party scripts (or isolate on subdomain without external links).
Add Referrer-Policy: no-referrer on sensitive pages.
Shorten token TTL and bind to IP/UA; invalidate upon navigation away.

reporter.description:
The API returns Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * with Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true, allowing any origin to read responses with cookies.

### Technical analysis
- Vulnerability class: **Misconfigured CORS**
- Affected target: `https://www.glaciervaultbank.foo/api/me`

```http
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true
```

### Why this is a security issue
The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

### Exploitation details
- Host malicious page and fetch protected endpoint with credentials.
- Observe successful JSON read in attacker origin.

### Recommendations
- Do not combine `Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *` with credentials.
- Reflect only allowlisted origins; disable credentials unless necessary.

The download endpoint authorizes by session only and does not verify ownership, allowing enumeration of other users' resources.

### Technical analysis
- Vulnerability class: **Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR)**
- Affected target: `https://www.glaciervaultbank.foo/api/documents/`

```http
GET /api/files/12345 HTTP/1.1
Host: victim.example
Cookie: session=...
```

### Why this is a security issue
The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

### Exploitation details
- Request your own resource by ID.
- Increment/decrement ID and observe cross-account access.

### Recommendations
- Authorize by object ownership on every read/write.
- Use opaque identifiers; avoid incremental IDs.

- Reflect only allowlisted origins; disable credentials unless necessary.

reporter.description:
The download endpoint authorizes by session only and does not verify ownership, allowing enumeration of other users' resources.

### Technical analysis
- Vulnerability class: **Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR)**
- Affected target: `https://api.glaciervaultbank.foo/v2/statements/`
- Preconditions: authenticated user: citizen; app version: Web 2025.09

```http
GET /api/files/12345 HTTP/1.1
Host: victim.example
Cookie: session=...
```

### Why this is a security issue
The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

### Exploitation details
- Request your own resource by ID.
- Increment/decrement ID and observe cross-account access.

### Recommendations
- Authorize by object ownership on every read/write.
- Use opaque identifiers; avoid incremental IDs.
